abstract.p: Alden Olson letter comments on May 16 on cybersex addiction; drawing

block.p: ''Cybersex Gives Birth to a Psychological Disorder'' and ''First Step Is Recognizing the Signs of Internet Abuse'' on May 16 alert the reader to the dangerous similarities between compulsive cybersex and drug addiction. Yet the articles would read about the same after one substituted for ''cybersex'' the word ''golf.''

Both activities, for example, can easily meet the quoted definition of an addiction: ''Loss of control, continuation of the behavior despite significant adverse consequences and preoccupation with obtaining the drug (or tee time) or pursuing the behavior (or whacking the ball).''

''Cybersex Gives Birth to a Psychological Disorder'' and ''First Step Is Recognizing the Signs of Internet Abuse'' on May 16 alert the reader to the dangerous similarities between compulsive cybersex and drug addiction. Yet the articles would read about the same after one substituted for ''cybersex'' the word ''golf.''

Both activities, for example, can easily meet the quoted definition of an addiction: ''Loss of control, continuation of the behavior despite significant adverse consequences and preoccupation with obtaining the drug (or tee time) or pursuing the behavior (or whacking the ball).''

Golf, too, has emptied pockets, wrecked homes and caused hours lost from work. The only differences I can see are that golf is pursued mainly in plain view and takes a lot more practice. And where are all the therapists for this condition?
